channel.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
channel.description:
If someone could Reproduce a RuneScape Client that would connect to localhost instead of a Runescape server, I could make a PHP script that would act as a packet editor by decoding the packets (The algorithm would take forever to decode, but it's possible), and then commence some packet editing code, then encoding the edited packets, and sending it to the RuneScape Server. And Vice Versa for Packets Received.
I don't know if making a Runescape Client reproduction that would send the packets to localhost, but I do know Packet Editing with PHP is possible, since I've done it before for another game successfully, including finding the packet encoding algorithm that the client used. (You can edit the IP the game connects to). There was so many exploits in that game, I found like 5 different ways to duplicate in that game. 4 of them using the same technique (MySQL injections in-game, which would make your character have a mini-rollback). The lead programmer is a piece of shit.
Or, someone could make a program that would loopback all the packets being sent to an IP on a certain port (ex 1234), and redirect outgoing connections to the Same IP except 1 port higher (ex 1235), to the same IP on the regular port (1234).
All these are very possible. Feedback?

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @RuneNhide RuneNhide
item.description:
@RuneNhide wrote:

I’m noob in runescape and yes I’m an idiot! Not because I’m using Delphi but cos I coded for sometimes witho/ aware of this thread. It supposed to be a client host app, with netstat clone to discover runescape’s socket n then sniff the packets (via PCap). And now thats all for nothing!

Westside Rep if u are still alive or interested to code the packet handling algorithm, mail me. I can adapt the app to run ur PHP script.

Read full topic

jo2305:

Wow… This might be THE PROJECT that kicks jagex’s ass! And it could possibly beat the turing test, too! Although it would take arduous work, and a computer with a hell of alot of RAM and a pretty fast internet connection (sounds like a dedicated server to me), this can be done! Runescape isn’t un-hackable after all! (Please excuse me for acting all giddy and crazy)

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @jo2305 jo2305
item.description:
@jo2305 wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:18, topic:234146”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=308733.msg2468112#msg2468112 date=1222822199]

If a human can do it by hand, then a computer can do it automatically.

Not so fast. In theory you may be right, but as of yet no one has written a program that passes the turing test, which is basically what you just said.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_test
[/quote]
I am sure that could be done with PHP/Mysql if you put enough time into “teaching” the Database first.
If the script looks for keywords then compares the surrounding context to a dictionary/thesaurus to find out what the hell the human is talking about. Then looking into the database for the closes possible match.[/quote]
Wow… This might be THE PROJECT that kicks jagex’s ass! And it could possibly beat the turing test, too! Although it would take arduous work, and a computer with a hell of alot of RAM and a pretty fast internet connection (sounds like a dedicated server to me), this can be done! Runescape isn’t un-hackable after all! (Please excuse me for acting all giddy and crazy)

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:28, topic:234146”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=308733.msg2469692#msg2469692 date=1222910309]
It’d probably just kick you from the server after the first mistake.
[/quote]
No, I meant have the client connect to a “server” running on localhost, where this server simply dumps whatever packets the client sends, then tries every possible response until the client does something indicating the correct packet was sent.
This is probably just an interesting concept at best, highly unfeasible.[/quote]

One incorrect response to the client and it usually automatically crashes. The client doesn’t take into consideration that the server is not perfect, so it will not try to fix unexpected data.

Read full topic

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:37, topic:234146”]How about modifying a client so that it always has the same packets, with each update. It just has some sort of converter code which just scans the incoming packets and tries to hook them up to the old functions?

Sure, the game server would kick you like a hundred times before the client has found the correct packet setup, but it might work…[/quote]

There’s no difference… you’ve still got to find the new packet ids, whether you do it in the actual bot or with some kind of external translator…

Read full topic

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“reVein, post:30, topic:234146”]It seems that you’re trying to recreate Autorune, if you can get your hands on the source it’d be a good start.[/quote]I have it…somewhere.

Not the latest though. Would anyone be interested in it?

I have a stack of around 10 HDDs, and it is on one of them.

As for Westside Rep.

You see, things get complicated at this point. You are correct in your regards to compairing packets by changing aspects of the game, however there is a little more to it than that. If you are interested, I could make a simple loader which loads the runescape client, with an extra button. When you push the button, it will print all the packets that have been sent since the last time you pushed it.

However, we are taking about hundreds (possibly thousands) of packets.

If you hook a loader up to a memory editor, you will quickly see how fast the editor fills with packets, and crashes.

So, in short, it would take a long time just to verify packet structure, yet alone IDs.

Another avenue is an “auto updater”, similar in logic to the updaters we run on the runescape client, but different in the method. However, this avenue would involve some serious algorithms on your end. So much so that I think it would not even be worth it.

Sorry to be sch a party pooper.

Read full topic

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @Westside_Rep Westside Rep
item.description:
@Westside_Rep wrote:

TL;DR:

Unhandled:

Well sure, but that’s just because apache is running as a server.

I’m talking about PHP - Apache. Just PHP alone…

I’ll show you what I mean. Here’s a very small potion of the Proxy server / Packet Editor I made for the other game.

Game & Server is executed by a small batch file:

@title Launching... @start game.exe @start server_loop.bat

In server_loop.bat:

@set path=./php/ @title proxy.php @:GO @php proxy.php @goto GO
This will loop a PHP script (If it crashes), which acts as the server.

portion of proxy.php:

[code]
…etc
$configdata = file(‘proxy.conf’);

foreach ($configdata as &$data){
$data = trim($data);
if ($data == ‘’)
unset($data);
}

list($local,$remote,$localport,$remoteport) = $configdata;

$proxy = new Proxy($local,$remote,$localport,$remoteport);
while (true){
$proxy->Pass();
usleep(10);
}[/code]

The while loop will loop the packet receiving, decryption, editing, encryption of the edited packets, and sending

portion of packet handling script:

$cbuf = @socket_read($this->client,4098);
if ($cbuf !== false){
	if ($cbuf == ''){
		out("CORE","Client disconnected");
		die();
	} else {
		$seformat = str_split(Packet::Decode($cbuf));
		$seformat = array_map('ord',$seformat);
		$format = str_split($cbuf);
		$format = array_map('ord',$format);
		out("SEND >>d",implode(' ',$format));
		file_put_contents("packet.log","SEND! ".time()." ".hex($cbuf)."\n",FILE_APPEND);
		file_put_contents("packet.log","SEND~ ".time()." ".hex(Packet::Decode($cbuf))."\n",FILE_APPEND);
		$bytes = str_split($decs=Packet::Decode($cbuf));
		$aid = ord($bytes[1]).'_'.ord($bytes[2]);
				$action = 'Unknown';
		if (substr($aid,0,3) == 127) $aid = '127';
		$msg = substr($decs,4,-1);
		switch ($aid){
			case '1_4': $action = 'login';
				break;
			case '1_5': $action = 'select-character';
				$selc = array_map('ord',str_split($msg));
				$msg = implode(' ',$selc);
				break;

				...More Packet ID's


				Example of a packet being edited (There was a bug in the game that made everyone around you disconnect if your text bubble was too large, discovered by me):

		if ($bytes[1].$bytes[2] == chr(21).chr(18) || // public
		    $bytes[1].$bytes[2] == chr(15).chr(18) || // global
			$bytes[1].$bytes[2] == chr(20).chr(18)){  // private
			$chatsize = ord($bytes[0])-4;
			if ($chatsize >= 6){
				if (substr(implode('',$bytes),5,4) == 'spam'){
					$dispchat = $bytes;
					$dispchat = array_map('ord',$dispchat);
					echo implode(' ',$dispchat)."\n".count($dispchat)." BEFORE\n\n";
					$chbytes = true;
					$xxx = 245;
					$bytes[0] = chr($xxx+4);
					echo "\nSpam trigger caught. Old $chatsize  New ".(ord($bytes[0])-4)."\n";
					for ($i=4;$i<($xxx+4);$i++)
						$bytes[$i] = 'W';
					$bytes[($xxx+4)] = chr(126);
					$dispchat = $bytes;
					$dispchat = array_map('ord',$dispchat);
					echo implode(' ',$dispchat)."\n".count($dispchat)." AFTER\n\n";
				}
			}
		}

The PHP script would be executed in a console window, like most other servers.

Unhandled:

What would the chances of brute forcing packets be? i.e, read what the client sends, then just send it every possible packet until it responds correctly…

Let’s see, you’d take the total amount of bytes in a packet, We’ll name it x, and then you apply it to this formula:
P = 255 * (x!)

So, if the packet we’re trying to brute force has a constant of 13 bytes, our equation would be:
P = 255 * (13121110987654321)

Which leaves us with a total of 1,587,890,304,000 different possibilities, with the average time it takes to send a packet to localhost being 1ms (0.001s), it would take approximately 51.6 years before it finished, and by then the packets would have been updated updated a few times, and Runescape would be dead.

BUT if it somehow succeeded, and Runescape DIDN’T die yet, seeing as how you’d have to do this for every other packet in the game (Let’s pretend there’s exactly 50,000 other packets), it would take approximately 2,581,230 years to finish, but that’s ONLY if all the packets magically succeeded with the same exact same structure, and all the IDs were the same as the current packet IDs, and all the packets would become obsolete in less than a week.

So I’d say it’s impossible.

Unless, of course, you have magic dust with you.

reVein:

It seems that you’re trying to recreate Autorune, if you can get your hands on the source it’d be a good start.

Whatever Language AutoRune was made in, I can’t do it.

Read full topic

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Taharok:

It’d probably just kick you from the server after the first mistake.

No, I meant have the client connect to a “server” running on localhost, where this server simply dumps whatever packets the client sends, then tries every possible response until the client does something indicating the correct packet was sent.
This is probably just an interesting concept at best, highly unfeasible.

Read full topic

item.title: Potential Runescape Packet Editor
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:26, topic:234146”][quote author=Westside Rep link=topic=308733.msg2468693#msg2468693 date=1222858718]
You’re right, but with PHP you don’t have to compile it and reopen the client everytime since the PHP script acts as the server. Everything I make is open source anyway, so if I do make the packet decoder (Which isn’t likely), It’ll be open source.
[/quote]
Well sure, but that’s just because apache is running as a server. You could easily make a Java app do the same thing.

What would the chances of brute forcing packets be? i.e, read what the client sends, then just send it every possible packet until it responds correctly…[/quote]

It’d probably just kick you from the server after the first mistake.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Westside Rep:

You’re right, but with PHP you don’t have to compile it and reopen the client everytime since the PHP script acts as the server. Everything I make is open source anyway, so if I do make the packet decoder (Which isn’t likely), It’ll be open source.

Well sure, but that’s just because apache is running as a server. You could easily make a Java app do the same thing.

What would the chances of brute forcing packets be? i.e, read what the client sends, then just send it every possible packet until it responds correctly…
